Joshua M. Moore's portfolio page ...

{

intro ...

After jobbing throughout high school, first at a grocery store and a furniture store, then at a kitchen, a hotel, and a TV station, Josh attended Seattle University. After taking a few CS classes and passing a higher level CS class, he switched majors to Computer Science and Software Engineering. After dropping out, he worked his way up from video game tester to senior software engineer.

He's a quick study, and an empathetic friend, if a little introverted and withdrawn. If you haven't heard from Josh in a while, you can reach him at moore.joshua@pm.me

Joshua is interested in graph theory. He spent the past decade trying to understand "Dynamic Multilevel Graph Visualization". He didn't say he was fast. Click four d for more!

}

resume ...

Peruse this beautiful handcrafted, machine squeezed PDF for my professional and academic (non) qualifications.

Joshua has been out of work since January.

}

{

eight queens ...

The eBook Eight Queens - 76 Solutions to the Eight Queens Problem is out now on Amazon! It features an introduction by myself, and beautiful artwork by Jordan Kump of ZoundsDesigns. Hardly any trees were killed for this book.

There's also the web page I used to create the pages for the book. Check out the source code for an example of a web worker in action.

And of course, you can find the source at github.

}

{

fourd ...

FourD is a utility for displaying small, but dynamic graphs inside of web pages. Here is an example:

This implementation follows along the physics metaphor introduced in Dynamic Multilevel Graph Visualization (Veldhuizen 2007):

  • Vertices (the black boxes) repel each other as if by magnetic force.
  • Edges pull two vertices back together, as if they were springs.
  • The result is an automatic layout of all supplied vertices and edges.
After that, it's a lotta bit of calculus. There are four main commands to this widget:
  • vertex add_vertex( options )
  • void remove_vertex( vertex.id )
  • edge add_edge( source.id, target.id, options )
  • void remove_edge( edge.id )
You can find the source code to the whole thing here.

}

{

social cartography ...

CASG is a perpetually unfinished prototype for editing 3D graphs, and saving them - PGP encrypted - to your RemoteStorage.js account or your device. Betraying the S in the name, it does not currently do sharing. This will be the case until someone gives me a round toit. social-cartography.github.io

}

{

learn ECMAScript ...

This interactive tutorial by Nathan Whitehead, rehosted for your convenience, will take you from someone who kinda understands what Javascript does to someone who targets javascript writing their own programming languages. Yes, my advanced folk, this tutorial really is that good. Bear with the beginners for the first few moments. learnes

}
